div1.p: Sweet provides a detailed account of the vessels traveling between the Pacific Coast of the Americas and Asia.

div1.head: Letter from E.A. Sweet to Henry Rose Carter, June 1, 1923
div1.opener:
6) 521 8 1/3
43
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
HONOLULU QUARANTINE STATION
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
HONOLULU
June 1, 1923
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter
U. S. Public Health Service
Washington, D. C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
The information requested in your letter of the 15th ultimo
regarding vessels from the Pacific coast of the Americas destined
for Asiatic ports is as follows, as far as those stopping at Hawaii
is concerned. I think you understand, however, that there are other
lines between the points mentioned which do not call at these is-
lands, and I am sorry that I cannot also give you this information.

T. K. K. South American lines: The itinerary of these vessels
includes Valparaiso, Antofagasta, Iquique, Callao, Balboa, Manzanillo,
San Pedro or San Francisco, and the Asiatic ports of Yokohama, Kobe,
and Hongkong. A vessel covering this itinerary calls at Honolulu and
Hilo about every six weeks. We regard them as constituting our great-
est menace, as far as yellow fever is concerned. It has been our cus-
tom to hold ships of this class for fumigation outside the harbor, but
in case they have been fumigated by an Acting Assistant Surgeon at
Callao and do not enter a Mexican port, they are passed without treat-
ment. I believe that these ships also constitute our greatest danger
from typhus, as that disease has been present in epidemic form in Chile.

We inspect a number of tramp and sailing vessels covering a por-
tion of the above itinerary. Most of these ships, however, are nitrate
vessels from Iquique, and practically none of them are for Asiatic
ports direct.

Pacific Mail lines: The itinerary of these vessels includes San
Francisco, Honolulu, Yokohama, Kobe, Shanghai, Hongkong, and Manila.
Vessels of this line at one time called at Calcutta, but this service
has been discontinued.

In addition to the above established line, we also have a con-
siderable number of freighters coming through the Canal going to such
Oriental ports as Shanghai, Hongkong, Saigon, Cebu, Iloilo, and even
to Java. Going out they carry oil, steel products, and general cargo.
Returning they carry mostly sugar.

T. K. K. lines, San Francisco to the Orient: These vessels have
practically the same itinerary as those of the Pacific Mail S.S. Co.

Oceanic S.S. Co: San Francisco to Sydney stopping at Honolulu and
Pago Pago.

In addition to the above there are also a number of tramp vessels
leaving the west coast for Australian and New Zealand ports, most of
them taking lumber down.

Canadian Australasian S.S. Co: Vancouver to Sydney, calling at
Honolulu, Suva, and Auckland.

China Mail S.S. Co: San Francisco, Honolulu, Yokohama, Kobe,
Shanghai, and Hongkong.

In addition to the foregoing, we of course have the Army trans-
ports between San Francisco and Manila via Honolulu, but occasionally
stopping on the return trip at Mojii and other Japanese ports. I
think this includes about everything we have.
With very king regards, I am
